sub_title: Associate Professor in sociology of digital health
summary: I work as an associate professor in the sociology of digital health at the department of Healthcare Governance at the Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management. My background is in the interdisciplinary field of Science & Technology Studies, combining perspectives from sociology (of science), anthropology and philosophy of technology. Working from a socio-technical approach that takes the intertwinement of technological and social developments as analytical focus, my research work focuses on the various implications of the transformation to digital health for healthcare practitioners and patients. I use qualitative and ethnographic research methods to study technological developments 'up close'.

As a part of the EU-funded project Big Medilytics (https://www.bigmedilytics.eu/), he is involved in an international comparison of formal and informal rules for Big Data in various European countries.

profile_positions.description:
Currently I am working on a post-doc project entitled 'Exploring healthcare professionals’ understanding of the experiences and practical challenges of chronically ill patients through the Imitation Game'. This research addresses the extent to which different groups of professionals are able to understand the experiences and practical challenges of patients with chronic diseases. For this purpose, an innovative research method known as the 'Imitation Game' is used. This is a blinded, computer-based experiment consisting of a judge (from a specific target group) asking questions and two respondents – one is from the same target group, answering naturally, and the other is pretending to be from this target group.

In this particular research, the judge asking questions will be a chronically ill patient, asking questions about the experiences and meanings of living with a chronic illness. One respondent, who will be another patient suffering from the same chronic illness, will answer naturally. The second respondent, who will be a health care professional, will be pretending to be a chronically ill patient. It is the judges’ task to figure out who is who. This method provides both a quantitative way to investigate the extent to which professionals are able to connect to the experiences of chronically ill patients as well as a rich source of qualitative insights that are of crucial importance to these patients.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description:
My PhD research focused on how researchers, policy makers and professionals are coordinating their activities within the structural collaborative format of the Academic Collaborative Centers for Public Health (ACCs). The ACCs are long-term collaborations between Public Health Services, university departments and other relevant organizations. Their aim is twofold: on the one hand, enabling better research uptake and use of evidence-based methods in public health policy and practice organizations, on the other hand provide the incentives for health research to be increasingly targeted at local problems as experienced by policy makers and professionals. 

In my PhD research I empirically analyzed these structural partnerships in several ways: by focusing on their general development as well as an in-depth investigation of particular collaborative projects. Theoretically, I use several concepts to understand these processes, such as the notions of ‘boundary organizations’ (Guston, 1999), ‘front stage and back stage settings’(Goffman, 1990), ‘hybrid management’ (Miller, 2001), ‘Mode 2 science’ (Gibbons et al, 1994) and ‘communities of practice’ (Wenger, 1998).
